text: Edward Jenner established the practice of vaccination, inoculation with cowpox to prevent smallpox.
Louis Pasteur developed the first vaccines based on attenuated strains, such as the rabies vaccine.
Jenner’s discovery was based on earlier observations by Lady Mary Montagu and others that a mild case of smallpox could prevent future cases.
Ignaz Semmelweis and Joseph Lister showed that antiseptics could prevent transmission of pathogens from doctor to patient.
Koch’s postulates provide a set of criteria to establish a causative link between an infectious agent and a disease.
Robert Koch devised techniques of pure culture to container devised by Julius Petri.
Howard Florey and Ernst Chain purified the substance penicillin, the first commercial antibiotic to save human lives.
Alexander Fleming discovered that the Penicillium mold generates a substance that kills bacteria.
Dmitri Ivanovsky and Martinus Beijerinck discovered viruses as filterable infective particles.
Viruses, which may be harmful or beneficial, infect all kinds of cells.
